extensions.description: .cbl is the most common extension for COBOL source code files, containing the core logic and structure of the program.
.cob is an alternative extension for COBOL source code files, often used interchangeably with .cbl in various development environments.
.cpy is used for COBOL copybook files, which define reusable data structures or sections of code that are included in multiple programs via the COPY directive.
.int represents intermediate code files generated during the compilation process, containing COBOL code in a partially compiled form for execution or further optimization.
.obj refers to object files containing compiled binary code that is ready for linking but not yet executable. These files are generated during the compilation process.
.dll is used for Dynamic Link Library files in Windows environments, containing precompiled COBOL routines or functions that can be reused by multiple programs.
.so refers to shared object files used in Unix/Linux environments, similar to .dll files in Windows, containing precompiled routines that can be dynamically linked at runtime.
.dat files are used to store structured information in either binary or text format, often accessed by COBOL programs for file-based input/output operations.
.idx files are index files associated with indexed data files, used to improve the efficiency of record retrieval in indexed file structures.
.txt is used for plain text files that may store data or configuration information in a simple, human-readable format.
.vsam files are used in IBM mainframe environments, utilizing the Virtual Storage Access Method (VSAM) to manage large and complex datasets.
.lst refers to listing files generated during the compilation process, providing detailed output including source code, line numbers, and any compilation errors or warnings.
.log files capture execution details, error messages, or other runtime information useful for debugging and monitoring program behavior.
.exe is the extension for executable files in Windows environments, representing the final compiled and linked COBOL program ready for execution.
.bin files are binary executables commonly used in Unix/Linux or mainframe environments to represent compiled COBOL programs.
.run is used for control files or execution scripts that automate the running of COBOL programs, often in mainframe or legacy systems.
.cmd refers to command script files used to execute COBOL programs or related commands in Windows environments.
.bat is used for batch files that contain a series of commands to be executed, often used to run COBOL programs or manage their execution in Windows environments.
